title: This Week’s Weird and Wonderful—January 9, 2025
description: It's time to take a look at what's making us chuckle and/or double-take in this week's crop of BaT listings. In order to make sure that you, our loyal readers, don't miss out, we take time every Friday to call attention to some of the most unique, important, and strange vehicles on our pages.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Learn more about This Week’s Weird and Wonderful—January 9, 2025 on Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online.
text: It’s time to take a look at what’s making us chuckle and/or double-take in this week’s crop of BaT listings. In order to make sure that you, our loyal readers, don’t miss out, we take time every Friday to call attention to some of the most unique, important, and strange vehicles on our pages. This is by no means a comprehensive list—there are far too many highlights to feature them all. But that’s what our make and model directory and live auctions page are for! Here are 10 of the listings that stood out to us this week, plus a few honorable mentions. 1. DeLar Custom Coupe Let’s start with the odd, shall we? This custom creation (called the “DeLar”) is an original take on “neoclassic” style, rendered in right angles. The search for a modern RWD frame led the builder to use one from a Dodge Dakota pickup, and the running gear is tried-and-true hot rod fare—SBC V8 paired with a TH350 slushbox. We have to say, we appreciate the cohesion and proportions of the design, and the attention to detail is impressive. It’s also refreshing to see externally-routed headers that aren’t just for show. This was clearly a labor of love for the owner, who took two years to complete the build. If any of you have a connection to 1980s David Byrne, please make sure he sees this listing. 2.  13k-Kilometer 1987 Porsche 959 Komfort Our first 959 of 2025! This one has undergone emissions modifications—it even has a California BAR sticker—and was recently serviced by Canepa to the tune of $95k. We can only quote the words of Car and Driver EIC emeritus Csaba Csere, who once said “The Porsche 959 can accomplish almost any automotive mission so well that to call it perfect is the mildest of overstatements.” 3. 1977 Alpine Renault A310 V6 It wouldn’t be Weird and Wonderful without a representative from l’Hexagone; this one hails from the town of Dieppe in Normandy. The V6-powered variant of the Alpine-Renault A310 was introduced in 1976 with revised styling from Robert Opron. Like the rally-proven A110, the A310 featured a backbone chassis under a fiberglass body shell and looked unlike anything else on the road—except for the stillborn Monteverdi Hai 450 SS, which was a more-or-less direct knock-off, styling-wise (Curbside Classic has an in-depth account of the design’s evolution). The A310 has a big presence for being really quite a small car—its 89.4″ wheelbase was the same as that of the contemporary Porsche 911, and it weighed a couple hundred pounds less. Also, are those the prettiest gauges Veglia ever made? They might be. 4. Custom 1948 DeSoto Roadster A 1948 DeSoto isn’t a model that gets singled out for customization very often, but park one in a pasture for several decades and someone creative might come along. That’s what happened with the seller @Phillb and this car. He describes this car as the “last project of our shop before closing it down…a fun car made from spare parts around the shop.” Take that with a grain of salt, because this car is full of tricks that are anything but off-the-shelf—flush taillights in the rear bumper, a reinforced tonneau/parade seat, and shaved door handles and rear lamps. Not content to sit behind the car in a lawn chair at car shows, Phillb kitted out the trunk for entertaining with a custom swing-out propane grille, three refrigerators, and a retractable LCD TV. @Cardogthreepedals and @Swampy_Meadows read our minds when they commented that this delightful DeSoto should be included in this post. 5. Targa Florio-Class-Winning 1960 Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint Zagato A grand total of 213 Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprints received aluminum Zagato bodies between 1960-1962. These beautiful, lightweight minimalist coupes were favored by privateers competing in the Targa Florio and other road rallies—Targapedia lists 16 examples of the GSZ in the field for the 1962 race. The team of Vito Coco and Vincenzo Arena piloted this car to a 7th place finish, nabbing a win in the 1,001-1,300cc class. The current owner found the car in France in the late 1990s, and after a refurbishment has driven it in several vintage rallies in Italy. It’s a joy to see a car with this kind of history being driven and enjoyed, and the period photos in the listing gallery are a real treat, as well. 6. 1968 Ford Mustang Fastback 135-Series 428 Cobra Jet 4-Speed & 1969 Chevrolet Camaro COPO L72 427/425 4-Speed These two carnivorous pony cars would have been drag strip rivals in the late 1960s. We last saw this ’68 Mustang Cobra Jet in 2022—it’s one of the 50 “135 series” cars built for Ford’s return to the Super Stock classes, which were inspired by dealership owner Bob Tasca, Sr.’s “win on Sunday, sell on Monday” philosophy. With some careful refreshing by the seller and a Marti report, this car carries the configuration in which these special competition Mustangs would have arrived at dealerships. Seeing the success of the Ford program, enterprising GM dealers like Don Yenko began to order strip-ready Camaros by specifying the cars with off-menu items that could only be ordered via Central Office Production Order (COPO). The Olympic Gold car here was ordered with code 9561, which equipped it with the 427/425 big block more commonly found in the contemporary Corvette. The original owner acquired it from Belmont Chevrolet-Oldsmobile in Weston, Ontario in exchange for one 1968 Oldsmobile 442 and $1,820 in cash. 7. 2019 Ginetta G55 GT4 SuperCup Race Car We think of Ginetta as a sort of spiritual successor to Colin Chapman’s Lotus, building lightweight race cars with the occasional road-going variant sprinkled in the mix. The G55 here is a purpose-built GT4 racer that competed in the Ginetta SuperCup one-make series, and is outfitted with air jacks, adjustable aero and suspension, spare parts, and everything else you need to go fast. Is sure sounds great ripping around the Apex Motor Club track in the video above. 8. 1963 Greeves Silverstone A little bike like this Greeves road racer needs a bit of context to appreciate properly. The black-and-white picture from manxnorton.com shows a Greeves Silverstone in its natural habitat, beneath Joe Dunphy at Mallory Park in 1963. Prior to this, Greeves competition efforts were conducted off of the pavement, primarily in trials events. When a racer named Reg Everett found success on a homebuilt Greeves road racing bike cobbled together from repurposed motorcross components, the company followed up on his efforts with the Silverstone 24RAS, which became a successful club racer pretty quickly. The sub-200-pound bike had some neat features like a cast aluminum “front bone,” a drillium engine cradle, and a hot 250cc two-stroke single that makes peak power around 7,400 rpm. 9. 1953 Cadillac M41A1 Walker Bulldog Light Tank It’s been two weeks since we featured a tank, and we were starting to get nervous. Thankfully, serial tank-purveyor @Wob came through with this betracked beauty—an M41A1 Walker Bulldog light tank built by Cadillac in 1953. Light is a relative term here, of course—it’s not going to qualify for BaT Shipping. Cadillac was actually the main supplier of the Walker Bulldog for the first half of the 1950s, operating out of the same Cleveland facility where Fisher Body built parts for B-29 bombers during WWII. Nobody at the DMV will know this, of course, so just call it a “1953 Cadillac” and see if you can get plates issued. 10. 13B Rotary-Powered 1985 Renault R5 Turbo 2 Yes, we have already featured a French car, but it is the distinctly un-French part of this Renault 5 Turbo 2 that puts it on the list for this week’s post. Under the carpeted engine cover behind the passenger compartment resides a Mazda 13B rotary with a Turbonetics turbocharger, which could put down substantially more than the R5T2’s stock 158 horsepower depending on the particulars of the tune. We really dig creative engine swaps like this, and the sale includes the removed engine and associated components. Honorable Mentions We had trouble keeping the main list to 10 vehicles this week, so of course there are a few more listings worth calling attention to. Honorable Mention: 1977 Dodge D100 Warlock Utiline 360 As the wave of patriotic fervor from our nation’s bicentennial faded in the rearview, Dodge turned to other cultural phenomena to inspire their “Adult Toys” lineup of trucks—here, presumably, the fantasy tabletop role-playing game Dungeons & Dragons. The occult influences that produced the Warlock ultimately conjured an appearance package that was not remotely as evil as it sounded, consisting of gold tape stripes, bucket seats, gold-painted steelies, chrome bed steps, and oak sideboards. Honorable Mentions: 1972 Honda Z600 4-Speed & 2001 Honda Insight 5-Speed These two hyper-miling Hondas make a fantastic pairing. The Z600, with its air-cooled 598cc twin, got an estimated 42 mpg in highway driving when new. Nearly 30 years later, the Insight achieved even greater efficiency with a hefty dollop of engineering. These days, pavement-pounding hybrid-electric vehicles are the norm in the marketplace, but the Insight was designed to sip fuel at a miserly pace. Its lightweight body, tapered toward the back, slid through the air with a drag coefficient of 0.25. Owners reported driving over 600 miles on one 10-gallon tank of gas. Honorable Mention: 1966 Wards Riverside 250 That’s “Wards” as in “Montgomery.” This 250cc sport bike was a rebadged Benelli that was sold by the department store chain. Near the register, we assume, as it would have made an excellent impulse buy. Like we said, this list is by no means comprehensive; there are many more weird and wonderful vehicles on our pages at any moment. These are just some that we found noteworthy, but we’d love to hear what caught your eye! Let us know in the comments.
html:
It’s time to take a look at what’s making us chuckle and/or double-take in this week’s crop of BaT listings. In order to make sure that you, our loyal readers, don’t miss out, we take time every Friday to call attention to some of the most unique, important, and strange vehicles on our pages.

This is by no means a comprehensive list—there are far too many highlights to feature them all. But that’s what our make and model directory and live auctions page are for! Here are 10 of the listings that stood out to us this week, plus a few honorable mentions.

1. DeLar Custom Coupe

Let’s start with the odd, shall we? This custom creation (called the “DeLar”) is an original take on “neoclassic” style, rendered in right angles. The search for a modern RWD frame led the builder to use one from a Dodge Dakota pickup, and the running gear is tried-and-true hot rod fare—SBC V8 paired with a TH350 slushbox. We have to say, we appreciate the cohesion and proportions of the design, and the attention to detail is impressive. It’s also refreshing to see externally-routed headers that aren’t just for show. This was clearly a labor of love for the owner, who took two years to complete the build. If any of you have a connection to 1980s David Byrne, please make sure he sees this listing.

2.  13k-Kilometer 1987 Porsche 959 Komfort

Our first 959 of 2025! This one has undergone emissions modifications—it even has a California BAR sticker—and was recently serviced by Canepa to the tune of $95k. We can only quote the words of Car and Driver EIC emeritus Csaba Csere, who once said “The Porsche 959 can accomplish almost any automotive mission so well that to call it perfect is the mildest of overstatements.”

3. 1977 Alpine Renault A310 V6

It wouldn’t be Weird and Wonderful without a representative from l’Hexagone; this one hails from the town of Dieppe in Normandy. The V6-powered variant of the Alpine-Renault A310 was introduced in 1976 with revised styling from Robert Opron. Like the rally-proven A110, the A310 featured a backbone chassis under a fiberglass body shell and looked unlike anything else on the road—except for the stillborn Monteverdi Hai 450 SS, which was a more-or-less direct knock-off, styling-wise (Curbside Classic has an in-depth account of the design’s evolution). The A310 has a big presence for being really quite a small car—its 89.4″ wheelbase was the same as that of the contemporary Porsche 911, and it weighed a couple hundred pounds less. Also, are those the prettiest gauges Veglia ever made? They might be.

4. Custom 1948 DeSoto Roadster

A 1948 DeSoto isn’t a model that gets singled out for customization very often, but park one in a pasture for several decades and someone creative might come along. That’s what happened with the seller @Phillb and this car. He describes this car as the “last project of our shop before closing it down…a fun car made from spare parts around the shop.” Take that with a grain of salt, because this car is full of tricks that are anything but off-the-shelf—flush taillights in the rear bumper, a reinforced tonneau/parade seat, and shaved door handles and rear lamps.

Not content to sit behind the car in a lawn chair at car shows, Phillb kitted out the trunk for entertaining with a custom swing-out propane grille, three refrigerators, and a retractable LCD TV. @Cardogthreepedals and @Swampy_Meadows read our minds when they commented that this delightful DeSoto should be included in this post.

5. Targa Florio-Class-Winning 1960 Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint Zagato

A grand total of 213 Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprints received aluminum Zagato bodies between 1960-1962. These beautiful, lightweight minimalist coupes were favored by privateers competing in the Targa Florio and other road rallies—Targapedia lists 16 examples of the GSZ in the field for the 1962 race. The team of Vito Coco and Vincenzo Arena piloted this car to a 7th place finish, nabbing a win in the 1,001-1,300cc class. The current owner found the car in France in the late 1990s, and after a refurbishment has driven it in several vintage rallies in Italy. It’s a joy to see a car with this kind of history being driven and enjoyed, and the period photos in the listing gallery are a real treat, as well.

6. 1968 Ford Mustang Fastback 135-Series 428 Cobra Jet 4-Speed & 1969 Chevrolet Camaro COPO L72 427/425 4-Speed

These two carnivorous pony cars would have been drag strip rivals in the late 1960s. We last saw this ’68 Mustang Cobra Jet in 2022—it’s one of the 50 “135 series” cars built for Ford’s return to the Super Stock classes, which were inspired by dealership owner Bob Tasca, Sr.’s “win on Sunday, sell on Monday” philosophy. With some careful refreshing by the seller and a Marti report, this car carries the configuration in which these special competition Mustangs would have arrived at dealerships. Seeing the success of the Ford program, enterprising GM dealers like Don Yenko began to order strip-ready Camaros by specifying the cars with off-menu items that could only be ordered via Central Office Production Order (COPO). The Olympic Gold car here was ordered with code 9561, which equipped it with the 427/425 big block more commonly found in the contemporary Corvette. The original owner acquired it from Belmont Chevrolet-Oldsmobile in Weston, Ontario in exchange for one 1968 Oldsmobile 442 and $1,820 in cash.

7. 2019 Ginetta G55 GT4 SuperCup Race Car

We think of Ginetta as a sort of spiritual successor to Colin Chapman’s Lotus, building lightweight race cars with the occasional road-going variant sprinkled in the mix. The G55 here is a purpose-built GT4 racer that competed in the Ginetta SuperCup one-make series, and is outfitted with air jacks, adjustable aero and suspension, spare parts, and everything else you need to go fast. Is sure sounds great ripping around the Apex Motor Club track in the video above.

8. 1963 Greeves Silverstone

A little bike like this Greeves road racer needs a bit of context to appreciate properly. The black-and-white picture from manxnorton.com shows a Greeves Silverstone in its natural habitat, beneath Joe Dunphy at Mallory Park in 1963. Prior to this, Greeves competition efforts were conducted off of the pavement, primarily in trials events. When a racer named Reg Everett found success on a homebuilt Greeves road racing bike cobbled together from repurposed motorcross components, the company followed up on his efforts with the Silverstone 24RAS, which became a successful club racer pretty quickly. The sub-200-pound bike had some neat features like a cast aluminum “front bone,” a drillium engine cradle, and a hot 250cc two-stroke single that makes peak power around 7,400 rpm.

9. 1953 Cadillac M41A1 Walker Bulldog Light Tank

It’s been two weeks since we featured a tank, and we were starting to get nervous. Thankfully, serial tank-purveyor @Wob came through with this betracked beauty—an M41A1 Walker Bulldog light tank built by Cadillac in 1953. Light is a relative term here, of course—it’s not going to qualify for BaT Shipping. Cadillac was actually the main supplier of the Walker Bulldog for the first half of the 1950s, operating out of the same Cleveland facility where Fisher Body built parts for B-29 bombers during WWII. Nobody at the DMV will know this, of course, so just call it a “1953 Cadillac” and see if you can get plates issued.

10. 13B Rotary-Powered 1985 Renault R5 Turbo 2

Yes, we have already featured a French car, but it is the distinctly un-French part of this Renault 5 Turbo 2 that puts it on the list for this week’s post. Under the carpeted engine cover behind the passenger compartment resides a Mazda 13B rotary with a Turbonetics turbocharger, which could put down substantially more than the R5T2’s stock 158 horsepower depending on the particulars of the tune. We really dig creative engine swaps like this, and the sale includes the removed engine and associated components.

Honorable Mentions

We had trouble keeping the main list to 10 vehicles this week, so of course there are a few more listings worth calling attention to.

Honorable Mention: 1977 Dodge D100 Warlock Utiline 360

As the wave of patriotic fervor from our nation’s bicentennial faded in the rearview, Dodge turned to other cultural phenomena to inspire their “Adult Toys” lineup of trucks—here, presumably, the fantasy tabletop role-playing game Dungeons & Dragons. The occult influences that produced the Warlock ultimately conjured an appearance package that was not remotely as evil as it sounded, consisting of gold tape stripes, bucket seats, gold-painted steelies, chrome bed steps, and oak sideboards.

Honorable Mentions: 1972 Honda Z600 4-Speed & 2001 Honda Insight 5-Speed

These two hyper-miling Hondas make a fantastic pairing. The Z600, with its air-cooled 598cc twin, got an estimated 42 mpg in highway driving when new. Nearly 30 years later, the Insight achieved even greater efficiency with a hefty dollop of engineering. These days, pavement-pounding hybrid-electric vehicles are the norm in the marketplace, but the Insight was designed to sip fuel at a miserly pace. Its lightweight body, tapered toward the back, slid through the air with a drag coefficient of 0.25. Owners reported driving over 600 miles on one 10-gallon tank of gas.

Honorable Mention: 1966 Wards Riverside 250

That’s “Wards” as in “Montgomery.” This 250cc sport bike was a rebadged Benelli that was sold by the department store chain. Near the register, we assume, as it would have made an excellent impulse buy.

Like we said, this list is by no means comprehensive; there are many more weird and wonderful vehicles on our pages at any moment. These are just some that we found noteworthy, but we’d love to hear what caught your eye! Let us know in the comments.
